content.description: The manager of a restaurant plans to survey a random sample of customers to estimate the proportion of customers who would return within a week if given a coupon for a free dessert to use on their next visit. A similar coupon was given last year, and <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent of the customers who were given the coupon returned within a week. The manager will use the observed proportion from last year as a preliminary estimate of the population proportion and wants the margin of error to be at most <math alttext="0.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.04</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> at a <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent level of confidence.
content.question: Of the following, which is the least number of customers who should be surveyed such that the estimate of the margin of error of the <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> percent confidence interval will be no greater than <math alttext="0.04" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.04</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>?

topic.text: 6.2: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Proportion

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Construct a confidence interval, provided conditions for inference are met.
